slides.byline: Rob Spain, BCBA | Cristal Lopez, BCaBA | Megan Caluza, BCBA

slides.title: The Gap in Traditional FBA
bullets: Traditional FBAs focus on observable antecedents/consequences.
Many severe behaviors are driven by private events (rigid thoughts, experiential avoidance).
Internal triggers: "I'm stupid," "I can't do this," "It's too hard." → escape
Standard FBA misses the "function of thought."
slides.note: Visual: Iceberg graphic — top: aggression/refusal; bottom: private thoughts.

slides.title: A Dual-Lens Approach
slides.subtitle: Wrapping ACT within a Functional Assessment framework
bullets: Latency-Based Precursor Analysis: identify the thought before the behavior.
ACT-Informed BIPs: write psychological flexibility into the IEP.
Staff Training: teach paras to coach defusion, not just compliance.
Data: measure psychological flexibility (CPFQ) & academic tolerance.

slides.title: Part 1: The Assessment Phase
slides.subtitle: Identifying Internal Drivers of Behavior (Rob Spain)

slides.title: Identifying Internal Drivers
bullets: Transition from Standard FBA → ACT-Informed Assessment.
Method: Latency-Based Precursor Analysis.
Goal: identify early indicators of cognitive inflexibility before the explosion.

slides.title: Safe Assessment in Schools
bullets: Step 1: Environmental Assessment (Standard FBA).
Step 2: Clinical Measures (CPFQ).
Step 3: "Test" conditions — measure latency to the first precursor.
slides.note: Example precursor: head down, "This is dumb" → stop test.

slides.title: Differentiating the Function
bullets: Graph: latency to precursor across conditions.
Short latency in "Rigid Rule" vs. control.
Takeaway: thought drives behavior, not just the task.

slides.title: Writing ACT into the IEP
bullets: Challenge: make acceptance measurable and legally defensible.
Solution: adapt the standard BIP template.
slides.note: Visual: BIP template with ACT columns.

slides.title: Replacements > Reductions
bullets: Old goal: reduce task refusal to 0.
New goal: when frustrated, student uses a defusion strategy to complete 5 minutes of work (value: being a learner).
Key: tie behavior to what matters to the student.

slides.title: Teaching the Skills
bullets: Tools: structured curricula for Defusion & Acceptance.
Adaptive design: visuals for non-readers, metaphors for older students (Bus Driver, Tug of War).
Clinical example: DNA-V card or student visual.

slides.title: It Only Works if Staff Can Do It
bullets: Challenge: shift from command & control to coaching & connection.
Method: Behavioral Skills Training (BST).

slides.title: Teaching Staff to "Drop the Rope"
bullets: Instruction → Modeling → Rehearsal → Feedback.
Tool: fidelity checklist + coaching logs.

slides.title: Scaling It Up
bullets: Create systems that generalize across classrooms.
Train-the-trainer model + ongoing coaching.

slides.title: Does It Work?
bullets: CPFQ scores: increased psychological flexibility.
Externalizing behavior: decreased aggression/refusal.
Academic tolerance: increased work completion.

slides.title: Do They Like It?
bullets: Quotes from teachers, parents, students.
Theme: "He's not just behaving better; he's happier."

slides.title: The Future of School-Based ABA
bullets: Assess the thought.
Intervene with values.
Train with compassion.
Measure the life change.
